title: Fences
description: Fences within the City of Evanston.

title: Wards
description: The City of Evanston is divided into nine wards. One alderman is elected to represent each ward.

title: Federal historic districts
description: The National Register of Historic Places is part of the National Park Service. Four National Register historic districts have been designated in the City of Evanston. They consist of the Northeast, Ridge, Lakeshore and Oakton historic districts.

title: Crosswalks
description: The City of Evanston has just under 100 crosswalks ranging from pedestrian crossings to school crossing guard locations to senior crossings.

title: One-way streets
description: The City of Evanston uses one-way streets to help the flow of traffic and make driving safer along with other tools like speed humps and traffic circles.

title: Parking lots
description: This layer shows a parking lots within the City of Evanston as captured from aerial photos.

title: Precincts
description: The City of Evanston is divided into nine wards. Each ward is then sub-divided into precincts. One alderman is elected to represent each ward.

title: Bicycle routes, lanes, and paths
description: The City of Evanston has approximately 45 miles of protected bike lanes, bike lanes, bike routes and off-street paths.

title: Cul-de-sacs
description: The City of Evanston has just over 120 cul-de-sacs.

title: Zoning Districts
description: The Zoning Code is located in Title 6 of the Municipal City Code. The Zoning Code promotes the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, general welfare, objectives and policies of the comprehensive general plan. As adopted and amended by the Evanston City Council, the Zoning Code establishes and regulates buildings and building setbacks along streets, alleys, property lines, use of lot areas, parking and loading, and the areas of open space between and among surrounding buildings.

title: Refuse collection days
description: Trash is picked up in the City of Evanston on a four day schedule.

title: Bridges
description: Road and rail bridges in the City of Evanston.

title: Annexation Chronology
description: Annexations by the City of Evanston through the years.

title: Railroad tracks
description: The approximately 22.5 miles of railroad tracks in the City of Evanston are traveled by both CTA to Metra trains.

title: Recycling collection days
description: City of Evanston Public Works picks up recycling on a four day cycle.

title: Traffic circles
description: Traffic circles are a traffic calming device employed by the City of Evanston along with speed humps.

title: Census 2010 Tracts
description: The 18 tracts from the 2010 Census within the City of Evanston.

title: Problem Solving Team (PST) beats
description:
As a part of the?Field Operations Division, the Problem Solving Team's 
(PST) uniformed officers provide motorized patrol along with highly 
visible foot and bike patrol in neighborhoods. PST officers serve as a 
community policing mechanism by making personal contacts with area 
residents and merchants as well as providing a broad spectrum of 
proactive and preventive community services (attending neighborhood 
meetings/block club development, security surveys, etc.).

title: Overhead Bridges
description: Bridges over roadways in the City of Evanston along with clearance heights and height types.

title: Buildings
description: There are approximately 27,000 different structures in the City of Evanston ranging from buildings to garages to decks  patios to swimming pools. This layer consists of the footprints of the different sections of these structures. Large buildings with multiple levels are broken down into sections by number of stories.

title: The City of Evanston
description: The City of Evanston is approximately 7.8 square miles and bounded by Lake Michigan to the east, Chicago to the south, Skokie to the west, and Wilmette to the north.

title: Zoning overlay districts
description: The Zoning Code is located in Title 6 of the Municipal City Code. The Zoning Code promotes the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, general welfare, objectives and policies of the comprehensive general plan. As adopted and amended by the Evanston City Council, the Zoning Code establishes and regulates buildings and building setbacks along streets, alleys, property lines, use of lot areas, parking and loading, and the areas of open space between and among surrounding buildings.

title: CDBG Target Area
description: Each year, the City of Evanston receives approximately $2 million in federal Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) funds as an entitlement community of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). For more information see the City of Evanston's?web page?on the CDBG program.

title: Police patrol beats
description: Evanston Police Department divides the City of Evanston into eight patrol beats.

title: Addresses
description: The City of Evanston has just over 17,000 primary site addresses. This data does not include sub-units such as apartments, condominiums, or suites.

title: Beaches
description: The City of Evanston maintains 6 beaches along the beautiful shore of Lake Michigan, one of which is dedicated for use by dogs.

title: Water bodies
description: This layer shows bodies of water in and around the City of Evanston. The chief among these is Lake Michigan to the east with 4.25 miles of shoreline. The data also includes 3 miles of the North Shore Channel, the 14.2 acre Northwestern Lagoon, and various other ponds.

title: Streets and alleys
description: The City of Evanston has just over 1 square mile of street and alleys covering its surface which comes to about 13.5% of total land area. This layer shows the areas covered by streets and alleys, both paved and unpaved.

title: Census 2010 Block Groups
description: Block groups from the 2010 Census.

title: Driveways
description: This layer shows driveway edges within the City of Evanston.

title: Trees
description:
The City of Evanston has inventoried and maintains over 34,000 trees located on City property and in the parkways.

The data provided on trees located within the City of
Evanston was collected in 2014.? Maintenance and tree preservation efforts
are an ongoing part of the City operations, thus the data contained herein does
not represent current figures.

title: Temporary school one-way streets
description: The City of Evanston designates some streets around schools as temporary one-ways at certain times to facilitate safer pick-ups and drop-offs.

title: Traffic signal intersections
description: The City of Evanston has just under 120 intersections controlled by traffic signals.

title: TOD area parcels
description: A Transit Oriented Development (TOD) area is a development pattern created around a transit station that is characterized by higher density, mixed uses, pedestrian environment, reduced parking, and a direct and convenient access to the transit station. The initial boundaries and zones of each TOD area are described in Appendix A to Ordinance 60-O-15.

title: Tax Increment Financing (TIF) districts
description:
The City of Evanston has designated certain areas of the city as Tax Increment Financing, or TIF, districts. TIF Districts are established in compliance with State of Illinois 
statutes. The mechanism is designed to assist financially desirable 
developments that but for the financial assistance would not be able to 
achieve.

title: Special Service Areas (SSAs)
description:
A Special Service Area (SSA) is defined by Illinois State Statute as a 
contiguous area within a municipality or county in which special 
services are provided in addition to those services provided generally 
throughout the municipality or county. Special services include things 
like landscaping, advertising, public art, and extra garbage 
collections. The special services are paid from revenues collected from 
taxes levied or imposed upon property within that area.

title: Sidewalks
description: This layer shows the edges of paved sidewalks throughout the City of Evanston.

title: City Property
description: City of Evanston tax parcels with PIN, landuse, and a link to the Cook County Property Tax Portal.

title: Street centerlines
description: The City of Evanston has approximately 147 miles of street centerlines within its borders. These centerlines are coded with address ranges for use in geocoding and also includes honorary street names, speed limits, and ownership data. McCormick Blvd, while in Skokie, is included with this data as it serves as an important N-S thoroughfare.

title: Speed humps
description: Speed humps are a traffic calming device employed by the City of Evanston along with traffic circles.

title: Parks
description:
The City of Evanston maintains 76 of its own parks spread over 
273 acres. This parks layer also includes 10 Ridgeville Park District 
parks, 2 Lighthouse Park District Parks, 1 Cook County Forest Preserve 
(Perkins Woods) and the portion of the Canal Shores Golf Course within 
the City of Evanston as well as 2 parks just 
over the city's western boundary which we jointly operate with the 
Village of Skokie.
      .

title: Local historic districts
description: The City of Evanston's local historic districts consist of the Northeast, Ridge, and Lakeshore historic districts.
